normalised: Hey everyone, hope you are all doing well! Today, I wanted to chat a bit about something that is always fascinated me: the sheer variety of titles you encounter in the medical and healthcare field, especially here in India. It is not just "doctor" – oh no, it is so much more nuanced than that!

unnormalised: Think about it – you might first encounter a "Dr." at a local clinic for a general check-up. Then, if you're referred to a specialist, it could be "Prof." Sharma at AIIMS Delhi. And then you also hear people referring to "Bhaiyyaji Doctor" at the local community health center. It's a whole spectrum, isn't it? It can get quite confusing sometimes!
normalised: Think about it – you might first encounter a "D-r." at a local clinic for a general check-up. Then, if you are referred to a specialist, it could be "P-r-o-f." Sharma at A-I-I-M-S Delhi. And then you also hear people referring to "Bhaiyyaji Doctor" at the local community health center. It is a whole spectrum, isn't it? It can get quite confusing sometimes!

unnormalised: What I find particularly interesting is how these titles often carry different weights depending on the context. In a big, fancy hospital like Max Healthcare, "Dr." Gupta might be a seasoned consultant, while in a smaller nursing home, a "Dr." Banerjee could be a recent graduate. The title is the same, but the experience can be vastly different.

unnormalised: Then there are the honorifics. I remember my grandmother always referring to her family physician as "Vaidya Ji" even though he had a modern MBBS degree. It was a sign of respect and familiarity, a custom that blended traditional and modern medicine. And it's not just "Vaidya Ji"; there's also "Hakim Saab" in some communities, and so many other regional variations that reflect our rich cultural heritage.

unnormalised: We also can't forget the titles of those who are not directly "doctors," but play a critical role. Think about "Sr. Nurse" Mary at your local hospital, or "Pharmacist" Patel who always knows the right medication for your cough. They are just as important in the healthcare ecosystem and deserve the same amount of respect. I also wonder if titles such as "Yoga Instructor" and "Nutritionist" need more recognition as preventive healthcare becomes more popular.

It’s interesting to see how technology is shaping the landscape of medical titles. I think these are still evolving and will definitely need to be clarified as this domain grows.
